First off let me say this has been my all time favorite movie since I was taken to it at 3 years old, and our local theater played this every year until its first TV showing on February 29, 1976. I am not going to review the movie and story because most reviews here cover that (almost 5,000 of them) and it's all a 5 out of 5. The story, the people who made the film, in my opinion ended up bringing us the best motion picture ever made. Everything that was done in all stages of production was just absolutely perfect.

Here is where my problem comes in with the 45th and 50th anniversary editions (which as far as quality are the same, the same restoration).

 This is indeed a new complete remaster of the film and the clarity of everything is A-1. The details have NEVER looked sharper or more clear. Except all of the colors are wrong. Not many would notice this unless they are film purists or those who have seen this in the theaters from 1965 to the big reissue in 1973 would notice it (and have noticed it if you read the forums on blu-ray.com, Home Theater Forum and other film sites). The movie has been remastered about 10 times since VHS, every time it was different, and this is the only version that has the color palette it does. Everything is now in brown tones and many of the blue colors have been removed. This is not how the movie ever played in theaters. Even the director Robert Wise, who had complete control over the laserdisc box set, even his version is totally different in color.

 I hope when the 55th anniversary edition comes out, probably in 4k too, they restore it to its original colors. Way too much brown and beige. They changed the colors of the walls in the Trapp villa, and Julie Andrews hair changes from blond to a deep orange many times in the film. Please if you have ANY of the previous editions, check this out and compare colors. As I said the clarity and detail are fantastic, I don't know what resource was used to match colors, I don't think there was one. Plus the sound has been filtered on the high end to get rid of the tape hiss. Remember in 1965 there was no Dolby noise reduction, so there is a natural hiss in the sound. It has been removed here, but in doing that, all of the high end sound  from sound effects to musical instruments has been removed. Listen to the 40th anniversary edition and hear the rich high end tones (bells, strings, horns), they are gone on the blu-ray and 45th/50th anniversary editions. Why would this be done? Because studios today aim these releases at younger audiences who buy discs, and they are used to digital sound and ndemand no tape hiss. So they remove it to make it sound "digital" but in doing this they remove some of the original signal. If you watch the extra on the sound restoration, you can see the guy clipping off everything above a certain line. This my friends is the high end of the sound where the tape hiss is located, but also some of the sound from the movie, the highest frequencies of the orchestra and sound effects.  This edition is really good, the extras are incredible, but these 2 things are way off and thus being my all time favorite movie, I don't get the highest enjoyment from watching this knowing what they did. Hollywood has done this to many movies.

For this version, for the first time they used the original 6 track stereo master. For the first time they had the tools to be able to use it as I have read that it is quite worn. Trouble is, it must have had alot of tape hiss, because they removed it. If you listen to the soundtrack CD that came with the laserdisc, this used the 6 track master, but you can clearly hear that tape hiss. I would rather have the tape hiss there and hear the high frequencies of the music than have it taken away. The most accurate version (color and sound) is the 40th anniversary DVD, why they changed all the colors and cut off the high end sounds is beyond me.

I will never give this movie anything but the highest rating, I just thought people should know that there were some alterations done and they were not for the better. As great as this looks and sounds, it is not what played in cinemas during its original or 1973 reissue. 20th Century Fox PLEASE correct this for the 4k version, probably due in a few years on the 55th anniversary!

It's a musical, but like "Fiddler On the Roof," it tells the often unheard story of the people of Germany and Austria that wanted nothing to do with Hitler's war machine. Underneath all the turmoil, there is the inner turmoil of a military man who runs his family like an ships captain and his new nanny that brings the joy of music and childhood back to his house. And of course there is the "other woman," to add a little something to the romantic aspect. Well worth watching on so many levels

It's something you really have to prepare for. Patriotic songs, of course, however much it may be ridiculed - its status as a Christmas TV film is legendary - there's no denying that this is one of the best screen musicals ever made. As Maria, the lapsed nun who becomes governess to the von Trapp brood and weds their rather chilly papa (Plummer) before helping them outrun the Nazis, Andrews exudes a vibrancy that's hard to resist. But the real secret of the film's success lays in its brilliant songs ('Do-Re-Mi', 'Edelweiss', 'The Lonely Goatherd', 'and My Favorite Things'), every one of them is a toe-tapping classic which will buzz around your head for days. So, ignore those reservations and enjoy. Escapist films about, well, escaping; don't come any better than this.

This movie is cute and heartfelt, with great feel-good music, and a story that doesn't get boring despite the long run of 3 hours- but it can get a bit slow. As far as musicals go, "The Sound of Music" is one of the best musicals there is, and it still holds up well despite being an older movie. This is a movie that the entire family can enjoy, since at its heart it is the story of a family healing and sticking together. The cold captain thaws and stops being the emotionally distant and strict father he was to his 7 children (after his wife's death), thanks to Maria's influence. Maria also grows as a character, and learns to face the difficulties that come her way (after being hired as a babysitter for the captain's children), and learns to live her life after being sheltered at a convent. Then there are the children, who want their family back. Overall this is a classic musical, that makes for great family entertainment.

The Sound of Music is one of my all-time favorite movies. I grew up watching it on VHS with my family, back in the day where the movie was on two separate tapes and switching over to the second tape was the perfect intermission. I realized I didn't have it in my movie collection for some reason and, with the recent and sad passing of Charmian Carr, who played Liesl Von Trapp, I decided it was a great time to purchase it. Besides the beautiful singing, great acting, and amazing scenery, another reason I love this movie is because I was fortunate enough to visit Salzburg, Austria over 20 years ago. My family and I got to visit many of the scenes from the movie which is one of the reasons I love this movie so much.

The Sound of Music is based on the true story of the Von Trapp Family Singers. It was filmed in 1965 and the movie takes place in the late 1930s in Salzburg, Austria before the start of World War II. Fraulein Maria, played by Julie Andrews, is a headstrong, spunky postulant at an abbey. The Reverend Mother decides to send her to the home of Captain Von Trapp to become the new governess to his seven children. Captain Von Trapp, played by Christopher Plummer, runs a tight ship and expects his children to stick to a rigid schedule whereas Maria feels children should run and play. Maria loves to sing so there is a lot of singing in the movie and they are songs to which I've always remembered the words and it's fun to sing along with the movie.

I loved watching this movie after a long time and it was even better than I remember! This time, I was watching it from an adult's perspective and noticed things I hadn't seen before. The Sound of Music is a musical by Rodgers and Hammerstein and there is plenty of history as well as a love story. At 175 minutes, it's a long movie but there is still a couple minute intermission in the middle which is very convenient for a bathroom break. It is shown in color and can be watched in English Dolby Digital 5.1, English Dolby Surround 4.0, Spanish Dolby Surround and French Dolby Surround. It is rated G and I would love to show it to my kids someday once they have longer attention spans. This is the 50th Anniversary Edition and contains an optional sing-along track, a music machine sing-along and a Sound of Music Tour. The only regret I have is not buying it in Blu-Ray since the scenery is so gorgeous and that version would be more vibrant but the DVD is wonderful as well.

I love this movie and am so glad I finally own it (and it's not VHS!). If you also grew up watching this movie and have yet to own it, I'd recommend buying it since I feel it's money worth spent. We also purchased a copy for my mom since she loves this movie. Julie Andrews is one of my favorite actresses and she does a phenomenal job in the role of Maria. I love having this movie in my collection and recommend it to anyone who is a fan! So Long, Farewell!

A couple of weeks ago, I watched The Sound of Music for perhaps the umpteenth time since I first saw it in a theater way back in 1965. With my love for good old-fashioned musicals, I have  always ranked this film very high on my Top 10 list of all-time favorite movies.

For those not familiar with The Sound of Music, the film is based on the famous Rodgers and Hammerstein Broadway musical also entitled The Sound of Music. The play was based on Maria von Trapps memoir The Story of the Trapp Family Singers.

The Sound of Music is set in Austria during the years before the Nazis took over the country in 1938. Maria is an undisciplined, high-spirited novice at a convent. The convents Mother Superior sends Maria to work as a governess in the home of Captain von Trapp, a wealthy retired naval officer. Marias job is to care for von Trapps six unruly children. She and von Trapp sharply disagree on how to discipline the children. Von Trapp believes in strict, military style discipline, while Maria thinks an open, caring approach is better. The Sound of Music shows how Maria and von Trapp resolve their differences and form a loving family unit.

The Sound of Musics stars include Julie Andrews, Christopher Plummer, Peggy Wood, Richard Hayden, and Eleanor Parker. It has some of the best acting and most entertaining musical numbers Ive ever seen in a movie.

Over the years, I have watched The Sound of Music in nearly every home video format  videocassette (both Betamax and VHS), DVD, and Blu-ray. Until now, Ive found home video editions of this film disappointing. They always seemed to feature grainy and colorless video that displayed dust, dirt, and other flaws found in the original films. The videocassette versions were particularly bad, and DVD releases were only somewhat better.

When I first watched The Sound of Music 45th Anniversary Edition in 2010, I could immediately see that the film had been completely restored.  The high definition 1080p video quality is astounding from the very first frame. Colors are vivid and accurate, images are sharp and detailed, and film grain is natural but unobtrusive. There isn't any banding, crushing, dirt, speckles, or other flaws  anywhere to be seen. The lossless DTS Master Audio 7.1 soundtrack is rich and robust.

The 45th Anniversary edition of The Sound of Music is a three-disc combo-pack that contains a copy of the restored film on both Blu-ray disc and DVD. Theres a third disc that contains a wide variety of  outstanding bonus features. If youve never seen The Sound of Music in true high definition, or if you're simply  looking to upgrade to the best possible home video version, this edition is the one to get. Highly recommended.

First off let me say this has been my all time favorite movie since I was taken to it at 3 years old, and our local theater played this every year until its first TV showing on February 29, 1976. I am not going to review the movie and story because most reviews here cover that (almost 5,000 of them) and it's all a 5 out of 5. The story, the people who made the film, in my opinion ended up bringing us the best motion picture ever made. Everything that was done in all stages of production was just absolutely perfect.

Here is where my problem comes in with the 45th and 50th anniversary editions (which as far as quality are the same, the same restoration).

 This is indeed a new complete remaster of the film and the clarity of everything is A-1. The details have NEVER looked sharper or more clear. Except all of the colors are wrong. Not many would notice this unless they are film purists or those who have seen this in the theaters from 1965 to the big reissue in 1973 would notice it (and have noticed it if you read the forums on blu-ray.com, Home Theater Forum and other film sites). The movie has been remastered about 10 times since VHS, every time it was different, and this is the only version that has the color palette it does. Everything is now in brown tones and many of the blue colors have been removed. This is not how the movie ever played in theaters. Even the director Robert Wise, who had complete control over the laserdisc box set, even his version is totally different in color.

 I hope when the 55th anniversary edition comes out, probably in 4k too, they restore it to its original colors. Way too much brown and beige. They changed the colors of the walls in the Trapp villa, and Julie Andrews hair changes from blond to a deep orange many times in the film. Please if you have ANY of the previous editions, check this out and compare colors. As I said the clarity and detail are fantastic, I don't know what resource was used to match colors, I don't think there was one. Plus the sound has been filtered on the high end to get rid of the tape hiss. Remember in 1965 there was no Dolby noise reduction, so there is a natural hiss in the sound. It has been removed here, but in doing that, all of the high end sound  from sound effects to musical instruments has been removed. Listen to the 40th anniversary edition and hear the rich high end tones (bells, strings, horns), they are gone on the blu-ray and 45th/50th anniversary editions. Why would this be done? Because studios today aim these releases at younger audiences who buy discs, and they are used to digital sound and ndemand no tape hiss. So they remove it to make it sound "digital" but in doing this they remove some of the original signal. If you watch the extra on the sound restoration, you can see the guy clipping off everything above a certain line. This my friends is the high end of the sound where the tape hiss is located, but also some of the sound from the movie, the highest frequencies of the orchestra and sound effects.  This edition is really good, the extras are incredible, but these 2 things are way off and thus being my all time favorite movie, I don't get the highest enjoyment from watching this knowing what they did. Hollywood has done this to many movies.

For this version, for the first time they used the original 6 track stereo master. For the first time they had the tools to be able to use it as I have read that it is quite worn. Trouble is, it must have had alot of tape hiss, because they removed it. If you listen to the soundtrack CD that came with the laserdisc, this used the 6 track master, but you can clearly hear that tape hiss. I would rather have the tape hiss there and hear the high frequencies of the music than have it taken away. The most accurate version (color and sound) is the 40th anniversary DVD, why they changed all the colors and cut off the high end sounds is beyond me.

I will never give this movie anything but the highest rating, I just thought people should know that there were some alterations done and they were not for the better. As great as this looks and sounds, it is not what played in cinemas during its original or 1973 reissue. 20th Century Fox PLEASE correct this for the 4k version, probably due in a few years on the 55th anniversary!

The detail in this disc is amazing, even by today's standards, the colors are well saturated, the sound is great too, and the special features, which include commentaries by Julie Andrews, Christopher Plummer and director Robert Wise, a sing-along of all the songs in the film and an extra disc with an hour-long documentary of Julie Andrews going back to Selzburg 50 years after the release of the film.

As far as musicals go, "The Sound of Music" is one of the best musicals there is, and it still holds up well despite being an older movie. This is a movie that the entire family can enjoy, since at its heart it is the story of a family healing and sticking together. The cold captain thaws and stops being the emotionally distant and strict father he was to his 7 children (after his wife's death), thanks to Maria's influence. Maria also grows as a character, and learns to face the difficulties that come her way (after being hired as a babysitter for the captain's children), and learns to live her life after being sheltered at a convent. Then there are the children, who want their family back. Overall this is a classic musical, that makes for great family entertainment.

The Sound of Music is one of my all-time favorite movies. I grew up watching it on VHS with my family, back in the day where the movie was on two separate tapes and switching over to the second tape was the perfect intermission. I realized I didn't have it in my movie collection for some reason and, with the recent and sad passing of Charmian Carr, who played Liesl Von Trapp, I decided it was a great time to purchase it. Besides the beautiful singing, great acting, and amazing scenery, another reason I love this movie is because I was fortunate enough to visit Salzburg, Austria over 20 years ago. My family and I got to visit many of the scenes from the movie which is one of the reasons I love this movie so much.

The Sound of Music is based on the true story of the Von Trapp Family Singers. It was filmed in 1965 and the movie takes place in the late 1930s in Salzburg, Austria before the start of World War II. Fraulein Maria, played by Julie Andrews, is a headstrong, spunky postulant at an abbey. The Reverend Mother decides to send her to the home of Captain Von Trapp to become the new governess to his seven children. Captain Von Trapp, played by Christopher Plummer, runs a tight ship and expects his children to stick to a rigid schedule whereas Maria feels children should run and play. Maria loves to sing so there is a lot of singing in the movie and they are songs to which I've always remembered the words and it's fun to sing along with the movie.

I loved watching this movie after a long time and it was even better than I remember! This time, I was watching it from an adult's perspective and noticed things I hadn't seen before. The Sound of Music is a musical by Rodgers and Hammerstein and there is plenty of history as well as a love story. At 175 minutes, it's a long movie but there is still a couple minute intermission in the middle which is very convenient for a bathroom break. It is shown in color and can be watched in English Dolby Digital 5.1, English Dolby Surround 4.0, Spanish Dolby Surround and French Dolby Surround. It is rated G and I would love to show it to my kids someday once they have longer attention spans. This is the 50th Anniversary Edition and contains an optional sing-along track, a music machine sing-along and a Sound of Music Tour. The only regret I have is not buying it in Blu-Ray since the scenery is so gorgeous and that version would be more vibrant but the DVD is wonderful as well.

We also purchased a copy for my mom since she loves this movie. Julie Andrews is one of my favorite actresses and she does a phenomenal job in the role of Maria. I love having this movie in my collection and recommend it to anyone who is a fan! So Long, Farewell!

A couple of weeks ago, I watched The Sound of Music for perhaps the umpteenth time since I first saw it in a theater way back in 1965. With my love for good old-fashioned musicals, I have  always ranked this film very high on my Top 10 list of all-time favorite movies.

For those not familiar with The Sound of Music, the film is based on the famous Rodgers and Hammerstein Broadway musical also entitled The Sound of Music. The play was based on Maria von Trapps memoir The Story of the Trapp Family Singers.

The Sound of Music is set in Austria during the years before the Nazis took over the country in 1938. Maria is an undisciplined, high-spirited novice at a convent. The convents Mother Superior sends Maria to work as a governess in the home of Captain von Trapp, a wealthy retired naval officer. Marias job is to care for von Trapps six unruly children. She and von Trapp sharply disagree on how to discipline the children. Von Trapp believes in strict, military style discipline, while Maria thinks an open, caring approach is better. The Sound of Music shows how Maria and von Trapp resolve their differences and form a loving family unit.

The Sound of Musics stars include Julie Andrews, Christopher Plummer, Peggy Wood, Richard Hayden, and Eleanor Parker. It has some of the best acting and most entertaining musical numbers Ive ever seen in a movie.

Over the years, I have watched The Sound of Music in nearly every home video format  videocassette (both Betamax and VHS), DVD, and Blu-ray. Until now, Ive found home video editions of this film disappointing. They always seemed to feature grainy and colorless video that displayed dust, dirt, and other flaws found in the original films. The videocassette versions were particularly bad, and DVD releases were only somewhat better.

When I first watched The Sound of Music 45th Anniversary Edition in 2010, I could immediately see that the film had been completely restored.  The high definition 1080p video quality is astounding from the very first frame. Colors are vivid and accurate, images are sharp and detailed, and film grain is natural but unobtrusive. There isn't any banding, crushing, dirt, speckles, or other flaws  anywhere to be seen. The lossless DTS Master Audio 7.1 soundtrack is rich and robust.

The 45th Anniversary edition of The Sound of Music is a three-disc combo-pack that contains a copy of the restored film on both Blu-ray disc and DVD. Theres a third disc that contains a wide variety of  outstanding bonus features. If youve never seen The Sound of Music in true high definition, or if you're simply  looking to upgrade to the best possible home video version, this edition is the one to get. Highly recommended.
